text: Posterior inference and marginal likelihood estimation are definitely related tasks, but just because you can do one doesn’t necessarily mean you can do the other. For example, MCMC can generate posterior samples, but doesn’t naturally yield an estimate of the normalizing constant. The question of how to use MCMC samples in order to estimate normalizing constants is an area of active research (see, e.g., <https://arxiv.org/abs/physics/9803008> or <https://auai.org/uai2015/proceedings/papers/120.pdf>). Some inference algorithms, including SMC, _do_ yield marginal likelihood estimates by design (though I’m not familiar enough with Turing’s SMC interface to know how to access them in Turing).
